title: Hierarchy, expertise and policy bureaucracy: a comparative analysis
abstractText: Policy making is about setting agendas and defining alternatives, but it is also about developing specific measures that might make policies work. Political leaders generally only have a broad grasp of the range of applied issues involved in making policy - such as how to put together legislation, organisational budgets or instructions to those charged with implementation. They must delegate much of this policy work to bureaucrats. This research looks at how such delegation works in six jurisdictions - the United Kingdom, France, Sweden, Germany, the United States and  the European Union. It explores the development of a sample of administrative regulations in each jurisdiction and talks to the people who wrote them. The patterns and norms of supervision and approval as well as the basis on which such officials exercise discretion when developing policy will be contrasted to explore cross-national variations in the conflict between hierarchy and expertise highlighted in the theoretical work of, among others, Max Weber and Alvin Gouldner.
organisation: London School of Economics & Pol Sci
